flowRoot.flowPara: We always need some data, X, often an m (records) by n (features) array. In a supervised task, we also have a target or label vector, y, of length m. Once we have data and a target, we can split them into training, validation and test sets:

text.tspan: X_train, X_, y_train, y_ = train_test_split(X, y, test_size=0.4)
X_val, X_test, y_val, y_test = train_test_split(X_, y_, test_size=0.5)

flowRoot.flowPara: Some machine learning methods require us to standardize X, meaning that we transform each column to a zero mean and standard deviation of 1:

text.tspan: X_val = scaler.transform(X_val) # Apply to all X.

flowRoot.flowPara: Let's treat this as a classification. First, we train the model...
... and evaluate how well we did:
It's also a good idea to check the performance against a dummy classifier:

flowPara.flowSpan: You need different metrics to evaluate regressions, e.g.

flowRoot.flowPara: In application, you'll be making predictions for new data. Scale it first!

text.tspan: X_new = scaler.transform(X_new) # Same scaler as before.

flowRoot.flowPara: When you deliver the model, the test dataset tells you how well it generalizes:
Let's treat this as a classification. First we train the model...
... and evaluate how well we did against the validation set:
In application, you'll be making predictions for new data. Remember to scale it first!
You need different metrics to evaluate regressions, e.g. mean_squared_error. When you deliver the model, use the test dataset to tell you how well it generalizes:
